We would have had a good hunch for a long time because we know the people with temporal lobe epilepsy, which is a form of epilepsy that affects the temporal lobes, and that's the portion of the brain behind the ears - they often experience sensations like this deja vecu or like day-to-day deja vu.
And we know that these areas of the brain in the temporal lobe are very important for memory and for recollection.
So we would have thought it was those kinds of areas.
And kind of happily for us that's - those are the areas where you see kind of damage in the brains of the people that we've managed to look at.

So we haven't got them in a scanner doing some kind of memory task and watching the brain whilst they have a sensation of deja vu, but we can look at the structure of the brain and how many cells are in any one area.
